intro: Mentha viridula, commonly known as green mint, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its small, two-lipped flowers are usually pink or purple, appearing in whorled clusters at the leaf axils. Mentha viridula is known for its strong mint scent and has been used historically in culinary and medicinal applications.
